questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of nausea over the past week. During this period, he has also had several episodes of nonbloody vomiting. Last month, he was diagnosed with stage II Hodgkin lymphoma and was started on adriamycin, bleomycin, vinblastine, and dacarbazine. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 95/min, and blood pressure is 105/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows cervical lymphadenopathy. The liver is palpated 1 to 2 cm below the right costal margin, and the spleen is palpated 2 to 3 cm below the left costal margin. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient is started on appropriate medication. Two weeks later, he develops headaches and states that his last bowel movement was 4 days ago. The patient was most likely treated with which of the following medications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Muscarinic antagonists, such as scopolamine, have an antiemetic effect at the area postrema of the medulla and cause peripheral inhibition of the intestinal tract's vagal nerve signals. They are mainly used for motion sickness or vestibular-induced nausea and vomiting and are not part of first-line treatment in patients with CINV. Adverse effects are related to their anticholinergic properties and can include mydriasis, tachycardia, and urinary retention.

B) INCORRECT:

Cannabinoid receptor agonists (synthetic cannabinoids), such as dronabinol, have peripheral antiemetic effects mainly due to decrease of intestinal motility. They can be used in the treatment of refractory emesis in patients with CINV. However, this patient presents with new-onset CINV, which should be treated with a different antiemetic drug. Moreover, synthetic cannabinoids have only moderate antiemetic effects compared to other antiemetic drugs and can cause a variety of unfavorable side effects, including sedation, vertigo, and dizziness, which this patient does not have.

C) INCORRECT:

NK1 antagonists (neurokinin receptor antagonists), such as aprepitant, have strong central and peripheral antiemetic effects. This group of drugs is useful in the treatment of patients with acute and delayed phases of CINV. Typical side effects include fatigue and hiccups. This patient, however, presents with headaches and constipation, making treatment with a different medication more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

H1 antagonists (antihistamines), such as dimenhydrinate, have an antiemetic effect in the CNS and may be used for vestibular nausea. They may also be used in women with hyperemesis gravidarum. However, this group of drugs is currently not part of first-line treatment in patients with CINV. Typical side effects of H1 antagonists include sedation and confusion, as well as symptoms related to their anticholinergic properties (mydriasis, blurred vision, and urinary retention).

E) INCORRECT:

GABAA agonists (benzodiazepines), such as lorazepam, have antiemetic effects mainly resulting from sedation and anxiety reduction. They can be useful in the treatment of patients developing anticipatory emesis in conjunction with CINV, or in patients with refractory nausea with contraindications to other medications. However, this patient presents with new-onset CINV, which should be treated with a different antiemetic drug. Typical side effects of benzodiazepines include confusion, impaired motor coordination, and respiratory depression.

F) INCORRECT:

D2 antagonists (dopamine receptor antagonists), such as prochlorperazine, have an antiemetic effect at the area postrema in the medulla. They are mainly used in women with severe hyperemesis gravidarum, or in patients with refractory nausea. However, this group of drugs is currently not part of first-line treatment in patients with CINV. Typical side effects include depression, fatigue, diarrhea, and hyperprolactinemia.

G) CORRECT:

Serotonin receptor antagonists (5-HT3 antagonists), such as ondansetron, block the 5-HT3 receptors of the area postrema and vagal nerve terminals and therefore have both central and peripheral antiemetic effects. They are especially effective for the management of CINV and postoperative nausea and vomiting. Side effects may include headaches, fatigue, constipation, and elevated liver enzymes. In severe cases, 5-HT3 antagonists may cause QT interval prolongation (which may lead to torsades de pointes), and serotonin syndrome if combined with serotoninergic drugs such as SSRIs.
questions.hint: This patient most likely has chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV). One of the most commonly used medications for CINV is ondansetron.

questions.text: Two weeks after starting chemotherapy with etoposide, a 66-year-old man with small cell lung cancer comes to the physician because of persistent nausea and vomiting. His symptoms improve significantly after the administration of metoclopramide. This patient's symptoms were most likely due to the effect of chemotherapy on which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The vestibular branch of the vestibulocochlear nerve sends input to the nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS), which is part of the vomiting center of the medulla. Conditions such as Ménière disease, labyrinthitis, and motion sickness can overstimulate the vestibular nerve and cause vomiting. The vestibular nerve is not directly involved in chemotherapy-induced nausea.

B) INCORRECT:

Intestinal smooth muscle cell function is required to maintain normal bowel motility and digestion. Conditions that impair intestinal motility, such as paralytic ileus, chronic dyspepsia, and Hirschsprung disease, can lead to nausea and vomiting. However, this is not a common site involved in chemotherapy-induced nausea and etoposide is not known to have any effect on intestinal smooth muscle cells.

Metoclopramide can enhance the effects of acetylcholine on intestinal smooth muscle, thereby promoting motility and accelerating gastric emptying.

C) INCORRECT:

The vagus nerve carries afferent input from the gastrointestinal tract to the nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS), which is part of the vomiting center of the medulla. The NTS responds to serotonin release from the GI tract, which sensitizes the vagus nerve and causes vomiting. This pathway is blocked both centrally and peripherally by serotonin receptor antagonists such as ondansetron and metoclopramide (at high doses). Chemotherapy-induced nausea occurs due to effects on a different structure.

D) INCORRECT:

The cerebral cortex sends input to the nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS) in the vomiting centers of the medulla. The cerebral cortex is involved in psychogenic vomiting, which can result from psychiatric disorders and/or emotional distress, and includes anticipatory emesis (which is commonly seen in patients receiving chemotherapy). However, the cerebral cortex is not directly affected in chemotherapy-induced nausea.

Anticipatory emesis can usually be treated with anxiolytics such as lorazepam. Metoclopramide is not typically used for psychogenic or stress-induced vomiting

E) CORRECT:

The area postrema is an area of the medulla that contains the chemoreceptor trigger zone (CTZ) and is one of the primary sites involved in chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting, along with the nucleus tractus solitarius. The area postrema of the brainstem has fenestrated capillaries, which allows input from substances in the blood such as drugs (e.g., chemotherapy) and/or hormones. Metoclopramide is a D2 dopamine receptor antagonist that acts primarily by inhibiting the vomiting centers of the area postrema.
questions.hint: Chemotherapy induces nausea by acting on the chemoreceptor trigger zone, which responds to certain chemicals in the blood. Metoclopramide is a dopamine receptor antagonist that is especially effective in chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting.

questions.text: A 73-year-old woman recently diagnosed with colonic adenocarcinoma comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of nausea and multiple episodes of vomiting. These symptoms started shortly after her first infusion of oxaliplatin and fluorouracil. The patient is started on an appropriate medication. Three weeks later, at a follow-up appointment, she states that she has developed headaches and constipation. The patient was most likely treated with a drug with which of the following mechanisms of action?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

H1 antagonists (antihistamines), such as dimenhydrinate, have an antiemetic effect in the CNS and may be used for vestibular nausea. They may also be used in women with hyperemesis gravidarum. However, this group of drugs is currently not part of first-line treatment in patients with chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting. Typical side effects of H1 antagonists include sedation and confusion, as well as symptoms related to their anticholinergic properties (mydriasis, blurred vision, and urinary retention).

B) INCORRECT:

GABAA agonists (benzodiazepines), such as lorazepam, have antiemetic effects mainly because they cause sedation and anxiety reduction. They can be useful in the treatment of patients who have anticipatory emesis in conjunction with chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV) or in patients with refractory nausea with contraindications to other medications. However, this patient presents with new-onset CINV, which should be treated with a different antiemetic drug. Typical side effects of benzodiazepines include confusion, impaired motor coordination, and respiratory depression, none of which are seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

M1 antagonists (muscarinic antagonists), such as scopolamine, have an antiemetic effect in the area postrema of the medulla and cause peripheral inhibition of the intestinal tract's vagal nerve signals. They are mainly used to treat motion sickness or vestibular-induced nausea and vomiting and are not part of first-line treatment in patients with chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting. Adverse effects of M1 antagonists are related to their anticholinergic properties and include mydriasis, tachycardia, and urinary retention, none of which are seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

D2 antagonists (dopamine receptor antagonists), such as prochlorperazine, have an antiemetic effect because they target the area postrema in the medulla. They are mainly used in women with severe hyperemesis gravidarum or in patients with refractory nausea. However, this group of drugs is currently not part of first-line treatment in patients with chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting. Typical side effects include depression, fatigue, diarrhea, and hyperprolactinemia, none of which are seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

NK1 antagonists (neurokinin receptor antagonists), such as aprepitant, have strong central and peripheral antiemetic effects. This group of drugs is useful in the treatment of patients with acute and delayed phases of chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting. Typical side effects include fatigue and hiccups. This patient, however, presents with headaches and constipation, which makes it more likely she received a different medication.

F) CORRECT:

5-HT3 antagonists, such as ondansetron, have a central-acting antiemetic effect and cause peripheral inhibition of the intestinal tract's vagal nerve signals. They are especially effective in relieving chemotherapy-induced and postoperative nausea and vomiting and are commonly used as first-line antiemetics. Possible side effects include headaches, constipation or diarrhea, and elevated liver enzymes. In severe cases, they may also cause QT interval prolongation (which may lead to torsades de pointes) and serotonin syndrome; caution should therefore be exercised in patients receiving frequent doses.

G) INCORRECT:

Cannabinoid receptor agonists (synthetic cannabinoids), such as dronabinol, have peripheral antiemetic effects mainly due to the fact that they decrease intestinal motility. They can be used in the treatment of refractory emesis in patients with chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV). However, this patient presents with new-onset CINV, which should be treated with a different antiemetic drug. Moreover, synthetic cannabinoids have only moderate antiemetic effects compared to other antiemetic drugs and can cause a variety of unfavorable side effects, including sedation, vertigo, and dizziness, none of which are seen in this patient.
questions.hint: Ondansetron is a common antiemetic drug, with adverse effects that include headache and constipation.

questions.text: Which one of the following diagnostic tests is indicated to evaluate for a potential adverse effect of using haloperidol and ondansetron in combination for the treatment of nausea?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A complete blood count with differential would be used to evaluate for agranulocytosis (e.g., due to clozapine) but is not the most appropriate diagnostic test to evaluate for adverse effects from haloperidol or ondansetron.

B) INCORRECT:

Hyperglycemia is an adverse effect of certain second-generation antipsychotics (e.g., olanzapine, clozapine). A basic metabolic panel is not the most appropriate diagnostic test to evaluate for adverse effects from haloperidol or ondansetron.

C) INCORRECT:

An echocardiogram is not the most appropriate diagnostic test to evaluate for adverse effects from haloperidol or ondansetron. The medications cause electrophysiological changes in the heart rather than structural ones.

D) INCORRECT:

Neuroimaging can be performed to evaluate for structural brain changes caused by certain medications (e.g., progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy in the setting of systemic immunomodulator or immunosuppressive therapy) but is not used to evaluate for adverse effects from haloperidol or ondansetron.

E) CORRECT:

Antiemetics that function through serotonin antagonism and dopamine antagonism can prolong the corrected QT (QTc) interval, which can predispose patients to potentially fatal ventricular arrhythmias such as torsade de pointes. Examples of serotonin antagonists include ondansetron, granisetron, and palonosetron. Examples of dopamine antagonists include haloperidol, metoclopramide, prochlorperazine, and promethazine.

Patients receiving these classes of medications should be monitored with electrocardiography, particularly if they are receiving high and frequent doses. If a patient receiving these medications has other risk factors for QTc prolongation, the lowest effective dose should be used, and alternative therapies should be considered. Importantly, if a patient has refractory symptoms and their primary goal of care is comfort, clinicians may follow the QTc less closely and instead select and titrate antiemetics as necessary to achieve symptom relief.

Key learning point: An important adverse effect of both ondansetron and haloperidol is prolongation of the corrected QT interval

questions.text: Which one of the following diagnostic tests should you order to evaluate for a potential adverse effect when using haloperidol and ondansetron together to treat nausea?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Neuroimaging can be performed to evaluate for structural brain changes caused by certain medications (e.g., progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy in the setting of systemic immunomodulator or immunosuppressive therapy) but is not used to evaluate for adverse effects from haloperidol or ondansetron.

B) INCORRECT:

An echocardiogram is not the most appropriate diagnostic test to evaluate for adverse effects from haloperidol or ondansetron. The medications cause electrophysiological changes in the heart rather than structural ones.

C) INCORRECT:

Hyperglycemia is an adverse effect of certain second-generation antipsychotics (e.g., olanzapine, clozapine). A basic metabolic panel is not the most appropriate diagnostic test to evaluate for adverse effects from haloperidol or ondansetron.

D) CORRECT:

Antiemetics that function through serotonin antagonism and dopamine antagonism can prolong the corrected QT (QTc) interval, which can predispose patients to potentially fatal ventricular arrhythmias such as torsade de pointes. Examples of serotonin antagonists include ondansetron, granisetron, and palonosetron. Examples of dopamine antagonists include haloperidol, metoclopramide, prochlorperazine, and promethazine.

Patients receiving these classes of medications should be monitored with electrocardiography, particularly if they are receiving high and frequent doses. If a patient receiving these medications has other risk factors for QTc prolongation, the lowest effective dose should be used, and alternative therapies should be considered. Importantly, if a patient has refractory symptoms and their primary goal of care is comfort, clinicians may follow the QTc less closely and instead select and titrate antiemetics as necessary to achieve symptom relief.

Key learning point: An important adverse effect of both ondansetron and haloperidol is prolongation of the corrected QT interval

E) INCORRECT:

A complete blood count with differential would be used to evaluate for agranulocytosis (e.g., due to clozapine) but is not the most appropriate diagnostic test to evaluate for adverse effects from haloperidol or ondansetron.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents with acute onset nausea, vomiting, and dizziness that began the previous evening and has progressively worsened. He has a history of Parkinson disease, atrial fibrillation, and recent chemotherapy for lung cancer completed 4 days ago. His medications include carbidopa-levodopa, warfarin, and ondansetron as needed, which he has been taking for nausea with inadequate relief. Vital signs are BP, 90/60; P, 110 irregular; T, 37.2°C (99.0°F). He appears dehydrated with delayed capillary refill. ECG shows atrial fibrillation with a normal QTc interval. What is the most appropriate pharmacological treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Scopolamine is specifically indicated for motion sickness and vestibular-induced nausea, not for delayed chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting.

B) INCORRECT:

Promethazine is primarily indicated for vestibular causes of nausea and is not the most appropriate choice for delayed chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting. Additionally, antihistamines can cause anticholinergic adverse effects (e.g., urinary retention, confusion) in older adults.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient is experiencing breakthrough delayed chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV) despite taking ondansetron. Dexamethasone is the appropriate additional antiemetic for delayed CINV and breakthrough symptoms when serotonin receptor antagonists alone are inadequate. Dexamethasone has central antiemetic effects and is not contraindicated in patients with Parkinson disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Prochlorperazine is a dopamine receptor antagonist that crosses the blood-brain barrier and is contraindicated in patients with Parkinson disease. This medication can cause extrapyramidal symptoms and worsen existing parkinsonism.

E) INCORRECT:

Metoclopramide is contraindicated in patients with Parkinson disease because it crosses the blood-brain barrier and can worsen parkinsonism by blocking dopamine receptors. Moreover, metoclopramide would exacerbate this patient's existing dopamine deficiency.
